bestBHT.bht: One notable mention in this section is Philologus, a common slave name. Philologus and Julia were possibly married, and all the saints that are with them could indicate the presence of another church in their home, suggesting a larger community of believers. The absence of any mention of Peter raises intriguing questions about his whereabouts in Rome at that time and challenges the traditional understanding of the succession of Roman bishops.

Philip Schaff: Romans 16:15. Julia; probably the wife of Philologus.
Olympas is the name of a man.
All the saints, etc. In any case pointing to a numerous body of Christians.
Archibald T. Robertson: Possibly these two were husband and wife.
All the saints that are with them. Possibly another church in the house.
John Gill: The first of these is a Greek name, and the name of a man, and signifies a lover of learning.
Reckoned among the seventy disciples, and is said to be bishop of Sinope.
Deserves some notice, that among all the persons here mentioned by name, known by the apostle to be at Rome, that he takes no notice of Peter.
John Wesley: Salute all the saints — Had St. Peter been then at Rome, St. Paul would doubtless have saluted him by name.
No one in this numerous catalogue was of an eminence comparable to his.
But if he was not then at Rome, the whole Roman tradition, with regard to the succession of their bishops, fails in the most fundamental article.
